entries.text: mdk announces that the Perl Quality Assurance website is now live, and that the next QA Hackaton will take place between the 12th and 14th of April.
entries.title: Improving the Tools

entries.text: Andy Lester breaks out the bad news (and by the same token give us 13 things we can work on to let the love flow).
entries.title: 13 Things People Hate about Your Open Source Docs

entries.text: You missed the Catalyst advent calendar the first time around? John Napiorkowski gives you a second chance to dig into that annual Holidays gift, and as a bonus provides a best of of all previous years.
entries.title: Catalyst Advent Wrap Up And Thoughts
Perl is not Dead, it is a Dead End - Welcome Moe
entries.text: Steven Little is know to be crazy and genious and also the creator of Moose. He published his slides from the Perl Oasis ranting about Perl, what else. The slides are full of vampirese. If that frightens you, you can read the Reddit discussion. On a second thought, maybe I'd go for the vampires...
Using Apache as a load balancer? Then you might look at the new API fREW concocted for its balancer manager.
entries.title: Announcing Apache::BalancerManager

entries.text: Joel Berger shows us how many lines it takes to have Mojolicious serve a directory and all its children as a static files. Spoiler: it's under ten.
entries.title: A quick static file webserver

entries.text: Michał Wojciechowski had some free time during the Holidays. In his case, this resulted in a first beta version of Arriba, a PSGI web server implementing the SPDY protocol. This is 2013, welcome to the future.
entries.title: Arriba – PSGI Web Server with SPDY Support

entries.text: Want to make the life of the translators working on your module easier? Then David Wheeler's Dist::Zilla::LocaleTextDomain is probably something you want to look into.
entries.title: Dist::Zilla::LocaleTextDomain for Translators

entries.text: tokuhirom released a first version of Perl::Build, which seems to be a programmatic sibling of the more cli-oriented perlbrew.
entries.title: Shipped Perl::Build 0.01!

entries.text: Sometimes, language is not even a barrier. One look at the code snippet of tokuhirom's blog entry is assured to make you go 'aaaaah....'.
entries.title: MetaCPAN web service API supports JSON callbacks
Introduction to building CPAN distributions
entries.text: Slides of the 30 minutes to CPAN talk given by David Oswald at the Thousand Oaks Perl Mongers.

entries.title: Any::Moose deprecated
entries.text: As Shawn M Moore (SARTAK) wrote, use Moo instead. According to MetaCPAN, currently there are 194 CPAN distributions depending on Any::Moose.

chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
